entries.text: If Perl is an important tool in your toolbox then follow what Ricardo SIGNES is asking you and test it. Before the release!
entries.title: Perl 5.16.0 is coming soon!

entries.text: After another long release cycle, Peter Lavender reports the new version of Padre. Two more and we arrive at the magical 1.00 release.
entries.title: Padre 0.96 has been released...

entries.text: The new round of the Send a Newbie to YAPC program was announced by Mark Keating.
entries.title: Send A Newbie

entries.text: This is the second weekly blog post published by Miguel Prz (niceperl). In this one he is listing the modules that gained the most +-es on MetaCPAN.
entries.title: (i) MetaCPAN favourites weekly report

entries.text: Carl Mäsak looks at a Perl 6 script that arrives to the same solution as his C program but 6 million times faster. That sounds crazy but interesting. He discusses the Perl 5 solution written by Salvador Fandino and then provides a Perl 6 solution to the same problem.
entries.title: Speed up by a factor of 6 million

entries.text: 'Ubic is a polymorphic service manager which makes creating daemons easy, while being extensible in a several different ways' writes Vyacheslav Matjukhin after a long break in reporting about his module. He mixes a big dose of technical update with information on talks showing the project and ideas about reaching out to potential users. Not only Perl developers.
entries.title: Ubic - status report

entries.text: Martin Evans
entries.title: RT fixes for Perl DBD::Oracle and request for people using TAF

entries.text: Aaron Trevena learns about the META directive of TT.
entries.title: This is why I love Template Toolkit

entries.text: by Joel Berger
entries.title: Alien::Base Perl Foundation Grant Report Month 2

entries.text: Do you use File::Slurp or write your own slurp() function? Do you use Proc::Fork or call fork() by yourself? What does chromatic do?
entries.title: Embrace the Little Conveniences

entries.text: Andy Lester offers his opinion on how to approach an open source project with patches. I am not sure. I think, while this make sense, is in contradiction with the earlier message: 'code speaks'. So what do you think?
entries.title: Before you write a patch, write an email

entries.text: Apparently the flow of reports from the QA Hackathons still has not dryed up. This time Geistteufel, the celogeek, wrote up a few words and add links to some pictures.
entries.title: Perl Hackathon QA 2012

entries.text: A few simple examples by Alexandr Gomoliako.
entries.title: Websockets in nginx-perl

entries.text: by Sinan Unur
entries.title: How do you pass the PostData argument to the Navigate method of IWebBrowser2 using Win32::OLE?

entries.text: Ron Savage has a a Perl-powered Toyota hybrid!
entries.title: My personalized Perl bumper sticker

entries.text: That's just scary.  (The second post of Chris Grau)
entries.title: Ninja Code

entries.title: Perl devroom @FOSDEM2012: photos

entries.text: Carl Mäsak breaks a month of blog-silence and writes about the Perl 6 hackathon in Oslo from his point of view.
entries.title: Revenge of the Oslo hackathon

entries.text: Tadeusz Sosnierz (tadzik) discovered that the Perl 6 Hackathon is better than bacon with maasdamer. Or at least on the same level. I think I am not supposed to comment on this.
entries.title: Back from Oslo

entries.text: by Moritz Lenz
entries.title: Perl 6 Hackathon in Oslo: Report From The Second Day

entries.text: by Jan Ingvoldstad
entries.title: Post-hackathon thoughts
Rakudo Star 2012.04 - a useful, usable, 'early adopter' distribution of Perl 6

chapters.header: Dave Cross announced his free Perl training in London which 'sold out' in a few hours. There is no point to link to it, but it is interesting to mention. Apparently, free sells well :).
chapters.title: Training

chapters.header: I usually include 3-4 of the nearest events. If your's is not here, I might not know about it. Let me know about it!
chapters.title: Events

header: It was late Sunday evening when I was trying to put together this edition and I was way too tired for this. At one point I noticed I was going over the same items I did last week. Clearly I need a better way to manage the links I collect. It is on its way but other tasks constantly get in front of it.
For this issue, I had to reduce the amount of comments so I could finish it before midnight.
BTW Miguel Prz (niceperl) started a new weekly posting. This time with his MetaCPAN favourites.
subject: Perl 5.16.0 is coming soon!
